title_sort: charles l. heyde to walt whitman, 7 february 1890
title: Charles L. Heyde to Walt Whitman, 7 February 1890
text: Burlington VT.Jany 2d 1890..Bro Walt.Han recd your note, with 1 dollar was too weakly to read it, just then. Is very poorly, feeble, nervous, emaciated, brain affected through prostration of physical power, from two very protracted attacks/jaundice & has taken much medicine, necessarily—has every edible thing suitable for her convalescence, yet does not acquire any energyweather very hindering, cold, or coldly damp—house comfortable however good heater in sitting room of course her disorder admitting no philosophy—she is sick—very sick" indeed Charlie"—Yet I feel encouraged that she will get better—well, after a time—can get up stairs and return—cook her own victuals, agreeable to herself——I gave a couple of paintings away (allmost[almost]) to buy a tin of coal and a few groceries—Neither Geo or Lou, write to her—might send her a trifle—Charlie— Charles L. Heyde to Walt Whitman, 7 February 1890
